title: The Bewties Of The Fute-ball
text:
The Bewties Of The Fute-ball is a brief, anonymous <a href="Middle%20Scots">Middle Scots</a> poem of the sixteenth century. It depicts the game of <a href="medieval%20football">medieval football</a>, as it was played in the same era, as being violent and unruly.
Historical context.
Ball games played between opposing teams were widespread in pre-modern Europe. Many localities are known to have had a variety including the <a href="Calcio%20Fiorentino">Calcio</a> of Florence and <a href="La%20Soule">La Soule</a> of northern France
In Scotland football games were common enough for the <a href="Parliament%20of%20Scotland">Scottish Parliament</a> to attempt to outlaw them on several occasions. An act of 1457, under <a href="James%20II%20of%20Scotland">James II</a>, is typical. The act was principally intended to encourage archery practice but decreed that football, and also <a href="golf">golf</a>, should be simultaneously discouraged.
or in translation,
Despite these bans, in 16th-century <a href="Perth%2C%20Scotland">Perth</a> apprentices progressing to become master craftsmen traditionally had to pay for a banquet and hold a football match. Several ball games which appear to predate the modern era exist in modern Scotland. The <a href="Kirkwall%20Ba%20game">Kirkwall Ba Game</a> is an example.
The text.
The Bewties Of The Fute-ball is preserved only in the <a href="Maitland%20Manuscripts">Maitland Folio Manuscript</a> of the latter sixteenth century. It consists of two pairs of rhyming <a href="couplet">couplet</a>s and it is attributed to no author.
